title: The Lovers

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of hemp, wool and silk, slit and double interlocking tapestry weave.

description: In the late Middle Ages, domestic spaces contained relatively little furniture, mostly utilitarian chests, cupboards, and benches. Textiles in the form of cushions, bed hangings, and tapestries provided softening elements of warmth and color. Although Flemish and northern French workshops produced monumental tapestry series for princes and cathedrals throughout Europe, in the cities of Basel and Strasbourg, on the upper reaches of the Rhine, weavers specialized in more modest tapestries. They included many woman artisans. Their tapestries featured witty, secular subjects—lovers pledging their faith (as here), fabulous animals, and wild men—and often had a gently moralizing tone, indebted to early engravings produced in the same region.
medium_display: Hemp, wool and silk, slit and double interlocking tapestry weave
inscriptions: Inscribed: ich·spil·mit·üch·in·trüwe / des·sol·üch·niemer·rüwen (I dally with you faithfully; I hope you will never regret it)

provenance_text: Possibly jointly owned by French and Company and Macdermid Parish-Watson, both of New York, before 1919. Possibly Joseph Brummer, New York, before 1919. Henry Corbin Lawrence (died 1919), New York; by descent to his wife, Lucy Ryerson Lawrence (d. 1920), to 1920; by descent to her daughters, Gladys Lawrence Hubbard and Lucy Lawrence Hutchinson, to 1921; sold, American Arts Association, New York, Henry C. Lawrence sale, January 27-29, 1921, lot 572, to French and Company; sold to Kate S. Buckingham, 1921 [on loan to the Art Institute of Chicago from Apr. 29, 1922, incoming receipt R375, loan number 2100.22]; given to the Art Institute, 1930.
